private_information: This peg currently holds five disks arranged top->bottom as A, B, C, D, E where A is the smallest and E is the largest.
peg_left.goal: Provide an exact description of my local stack and any constraints relevant to moving disks so the orchestrator can generate a PDDL model and problem.

peg_middle.goal: Provide an exact description of my local stack and any constraints relevant to moving disks so the orchestrator can generate a PDDL model and problem.

peg_right.goal: Provide an exact description of my local stack and any constraints relevant to moving disks so the orchestrator can generate a PDDL model and problem.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate the peg reports and produce a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem targeting the FastDownwards solver that solves the Tower of Hanoi instance: move all disks from left to right following the rules.

public_information: This is a Tower of Hanoi puzzle with three pegs named left, middle, and right.
There are 5 disks labeled A (smallest) through E (largest).
Only one disk can be moved at a time.
A larger disk cannot be placed on top of a smaller disk.
Initial configuration: left peg has (top->bottom) A, B, C, D, E; middle peg is empty; right peg is empty.
Goal configuration: right peg has (top->bottom) A, B, C, D, E; left and middle pegs are empty.

report.system_prompt: You are the agent responsible for the left peg. Describe exactly the contents and ordering of disks on your peg and any relevant constraints (for example which disk is on top). Do not produce PDDL output; produce a clear machine-readable and human-readable state description the orchestrator can consume.
report.prompt: Your name is peg_left. Use your private information to produce a concise description of the left peg state including disk order top-to-bottom and any constraints or observations useful for planning. The orchestrator will use this description to assemble a PDDL problem. Do not invent extra facts beyond what you know.

report.system_prompt: You are the agent responsible for the middle peg. Describe exactly the contents and ordering of disks on your peg and any relevant constraints. Do not produce PDDL output; produce a clear machine-readable and human-readable state description the orchestrator can consume.
report.prompt: Your name is peg_middle. Use your private information to produce a concise description of the middle peg state including disk order top-to-bottom and any constraints or observations useful for planning. The orchestrator will use this description to assemble a PDDL problem. Do not invent extra facts beyond what you know.

report.system_prompt: You are the agent responsible for the right peg. Describe exactly the contents and ordering of disks on your peg and any relevant constraints. Do not produce PDDL output; produce a clear machine-readable and human-readable state description the orchestrator can consume.
report.prompt: Your name is peg_right. Use your private information to produce a concise description of the right peg state including disk order top-to-bottom and any constraints or observations useful for planning. The orchestrator will use this description to assemble a PDDL problem. Do not invent extra facts beyond what you know.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent PDDL modeling and planning. Your job is to integrate the state descriptions from the peg agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem suitable for the FastDownwards planner. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep all agents actions distinct if modelling multiple actors, and ensure the model enforces that only one disk moves at a time and that larger disks cannot be placed on smaller ones. Target FastDownwards compatibility and use standard STRIPS-style predicates and actions.
pddl.prompt: Your name is orchestrator. You will receive the peg agents' state descriptions for a Tower of Hanoi instance with 5 disks and pegs left, middle, right. Integrate these descriptions and the public puzzle rules to produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem instance that FastDownwards can solve. Represent disks A-E, pegs left, middle, right, the initial stacking given by the peg reports, and the goal of moving all disks to the right peg preserving order. Provide clear type and predicate definitions, and actions that enforce moving one disk at a time and preventing larger-on-smaller placements. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
